results.title: A Pioneer stud
results.brief_description: One of the oldest established sheep studs in Australia provides the setting for this film; the stud has been in existence since 1827. The daily routine on this stud farm is studied in detail.

results.title: A Pinto for the Prince
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB, Colin Low and John Spotton
results.brief_description: In 1977, Prince Charles was inducted as honorary chief of the Blood Indians on their reserve in southwestern Alberta. The ceremony, conducted in the great Circle of the Sun Dance, commemorated the centennial anniversary of the original signing of Treaty 7 by Queen Victoria.

results.title: A Pint of milk
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, Australian National Film Board and Malcolm Otton
results.brief_description: One of a series of films designed for use in junior social studies classes. Shows how city people get their milk. Opens with scenes on a dairy farm- bringing in the herd, and milking the cows. The milk is taken to a depot, where it is tested for cleanliness, then sent by rail to the city. Here it is pasteurised and bottled then taken by the milk van to be delivered to homes in the city.

results.title: A Pig in a rocking chair; Mermaids don't need snorkels
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dandelion = Pusteblume”.
Two more episodes of the popular German children’s series Pusteblume (Dandelion). ” A Pig in a rocking chair” - Peter Lustig would like a pig, but where can he keep it in such restricted quarters? On the veranda in the rocking chair? Peter takes a look at how animals are properly kept on a farm where there are cows in the meadow and dogs, cats and doves have their own little house. The farmer and his family look after all these animals, because they derive their livelihood from eventually selling the animals. “Mermaids don’t need snorkels” - If you want to observe animals underwater, then it is best to use a snorkel, since this will allow you to breathe under the water. For really deep diving, it is necessary to take a bottle of oxygen attached to your back in order to look at sunken ships or to do research.

results.title: A Piece of the action
results.creator_credit: Melville Tucker, First Artists, Warner Bros Pictures and Sidney Poitier
results.brief_description: Bill Cosby and Sidney Poitier star as Dave and Manny, two Chicago crooks who have independently made a bundle ripping off rip-off artists who exploit the poor. But they have no intention of giving to the poor, until ex-Detective Burke pulls a con of his own - he anonymously gives the pair a choice, to donate time to a Community Centre or do time in a federal prison. Scrambling in their off-hours to find out who is blackmailing them, the two spend their working hours in classroom confrontations reminiscent of Poitier’s “To Sir With Love,” with 30 troubled ghetto kids. Cast includes James Earl Jones, Hope Clarke and Ja’net Du Bois.

results.title: A Piece of cake = Cest pas chinois
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gilles Gascon, Pierre Heberrt and Jacques Bobet
results.brief_description: The effortless style of the champion gymnast seems a piece of cake. Made without commentary, this film begins with eager young people going through their exercises in a school gymnasium and concludes with an exhibition of faultless gymnastics at the 1973 China-Canada competitions.

results.title: A Phoenix rising
results.brief_description: A documentary film showing how the community of Mt. Macedon is piecing together its life again after being annihilated by the fires of Ash Wednesday. The film is based on interviews with some of the residents and gives case studies of a couple of families. Written and narrated by John Bonney.

results.title: A Phantasy
results.brief_description: A surrealist abstract art film with pastel drawings and cut-out animation by Norman McLaren and music for saxophone and synthetic sound by Maurice Blackburn. In a dream-like landscape, inanimate but familiar objects come to life to disport themselves in grave dances and playful rituals. Music by Maurice Blackburn. (Awards: Venice, Toronto, Boston)

results.title: A Personal search
results.brief_description: In this autobiographical documentary, John Whitney, one of the best-known film and computer artists of our time, reflects on and explores his lifelong search for the complentarity of music and visual art, and the synthesis of film and computer technologies. In doing so, he describes current developments that foretell radical and exciting new ways viewers will soon be experiencing music and art.
